text: welcome to daily video vocabulary a dose
of daily new English phrases and words
brought to you by let's talk podcast
calm
for low English learners welcome to
daily video vocabulary
episode 19 today's new phrase is to go
haywire to go hey wire it's a very
strange phrase let's find out what it
means and how you can use this phrase in
your daily conversation to go haywire so
what do you mean by that let me give you
an example if you are to deliver a
presentation at the office meeting you
might feel like things are going haywire
when the presentation you made is got
deleted or the presentation file is not
opening to make last minute Corrections
things are going haywire the phrase to
go haywire means to become
uncontrollable or you can say to stop
working properly a lot of things are
going wrong or there are many things
that are going wrong usually you feel
like things have gone haywire when you
don't have a lot of control over them
the phrase haywire began to be used in
the USA as a slang at the turn of the
20th century the wire that was used by
many farmers to make their boundary
fences the wire rusted quickly with the
results that had an appearance of things
being out of control
hence originated the phrase haywire that
is things being out of control alright
let's look at some example sentences on
how to use this phrase in your daily
conversation example 1 my CD player goes
haywire every time my neighbor uses his
cordless phone
example two he arrived at work early
hoping to get a lot done but within
minutes things went haywire example
three I was talking to Mary when
suddenly the telephone went haywire
example four I was driving to Pune when
the car engine went haywire it was two
hours before the mechanic came
[Music]
